bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861-65.)

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: necrosis of pubis and urethral fistula from gunshot wound
wound remained open, urine passed through continually

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding, identified keyword terms
checked OCR; added minimal mark-up for personal names, place names, and dates

body.p: CASE 1049.—Private M. Keating, Co. D, 42d Pennsylvania, aged 33 years, was wounded at Bull Run, August 30, 1862. He was treated in hospitals at Washington, Baltimore, Point Lookout, and Philadelphia, entering Mower Hospital on October 1, 1863, and being discharged the service therefrom, June 21, 1864. Surgeon J. Hopkinson, U. S. V., on certificate of disability dated June 14, 1864, stated: "Necrosis of pubis, and urethral fistula, from gunshot wound." Disability one-third. Examining Surgeon H. L. Hodge, of Philadelphia, reported, June 21, 1864: "On account of gunshot wound of the pelvis his general health had been much impaired. The anterior wound still remains open, and urine passes through it continually; disability total." There is no record of this man since September 4, 1865, when he last drew his pension.
